Award.AwardTitle: Varieties with torus actions: algebra and combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project deals with studying the defining equations and higher syzygies of toric varieties, i.e., equivariant compactifications of algebraic tori. In general, it is difficult to find explicit equations for a given embedding. However, often one can determine the degrees of the defining equations as well as the degrees of the higher syzygies, and this information reveals geometric properties of the embedding. For example, the existence of nonlinear minimal syzygies is related to the existence of secant planes. An embedding of a toric variety into projective space corresponds to a lattice polytope, and the goal of this project is to further the understanding of the interplay between the defining equations and syzygies of the embedding and the combinatorial properties of the polytope. Explicit results for toric varieties can also be useful in giving bounds of the degrees of the generators and higher syzygies of varieties that are not toric, but admit a degeneration to a toric variety. For example, we apply this to the moduli space of points on the projective line.

Algebraic geometry is an area of mathematics that interacts with many other areas, such as number theory, topology, mathematical physics, and combinatorics. The most basic building blocks of the spaces studied in algebraic geometry are vanishing sets of polynomial equations. However, in general, the space in question is given abstractly, and often one does not know what these polynomial equations are. This project is about studying this question for a special class of geometric spaces that exhibit additional combinatorial structure allowing a more concrete approach than in the general case.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project my coauthors and I  studied varieties -- geometric objects that can be defined as zero sets of polynomial equations --  that admit additional symmetry via the action of a torus. In particular, toric varieties, which are partial equivariant compactifications of the algebraic torus. Often these varieties are given in abstract form, and it is a difficult question to actually describe their equations.  We determined equations of certain embeddings of moduli spaces of points on the projective line. More generally, one can associate to varieties with some additional data (a line bundle) an algebraic structure, called a ring, and we studied such rings associated to toric vector bundles and were suprised to find that they need not be finitely generated. We also studied singularities of affine toric rings -- corresponding to local patches of toric varieties -- using methods in finite characteristic.In a different direction we studied the action of the torus on the Hilbert scheme of points parameterizing collections of n points in the plane and found some necessary conditions for two fixed points to be connected by a one-dimensional torus orbit. We also found another surprising result, that there are only finitely many smooth toric varieties embedded by a complete linear system in a given projective space. Finally, we completed an applied project. Complex phase retrieval is used in image processing, and our bound determines a minimal number of measurements needed to make sure that the vector one wishes to determine  is  uniquely determined by the measurements, up to multiplication by a complex number on the unit circle. A highlight was an Research Experience for Undergraduate project, where the students surpassed our expectations. Building on work of Payne, two students found some very nice criteria for toric varieties to be diagonally split, a property that has very strong implications for the variety.
